head.title: Models of the Small WorldA Review

article.h1:
Models of the Small World
A Review

span.span:
M. E. J. Newman
Santa Fe Institute, 1399 Hyde Park Road, Santa Fe, NM 87501

div.p: It is believed that almost any pair of people in the world can be connected to one another by a short chain of intermediate acquaintances, of typical length about six. This phenomenon, colloquially referred to as the â€œsix degrees of separation,â€ has been the subject of considerable recent interest within the physics community. This paper provides a short review of the topic.

The United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs estimates that the population of the world exceeded six billion people for the first time on OctoberÂ 12, 1999. There is no doubt that the world of human society has become quite large in recent times. Nonetheless, people routinely claim that, global statistics notwithstanding, itâ€™s still a small world. And in a certain sense they are right. Despite the enormous number of people on the planet, the structure of social networksâ€”the map of who knows whomâ€”is such that we are all very closely connected to one another (KochenÂ 1989, WattsÂ 1999).

One of the first quantitative studies of the structure of social networks was performed in the late 1960s by Stanley Milgram, then at Harvard University (MilgramÂ 1967). He performed a simple experiment as follows. He took a number of letters addressed to a stockbroker acquaintance of his in Boston, Massachusetts, and distributed them to a random selection of people in Nebraska. (Evidently, he considered Nebraska to be about as far as you could get from Boston, in social terms, without falling off the end of the world.) His instructions were that the letters were to be sent to their addressee (the stockbroker) by passing them from person to person, and that, in addition, they could be passed only to someone whom the passer new on a first-name basis. Since it was not likely that the initial recipients of the letters were on a first-name basis with a Boston stockbroker, their best strategy was to pass their letter to someone whom they felt was nearer to the stockbroker in some social sense: perhaps someone they knew in the financial industry, or a friend in Massachusetts.

A reasonable number of Milgramâ€™s letters did eventually reach their destination, and Milgram found that it had only taken an average of six steps for a letter to get from Nebraska to Boston. He concluded, with a somewhat cavalier disregard for experimental niceties, that six was therefore the average number of acquaintances separating the pairs of people involved, and conjectured that a similar separation might characterize the relationship of any two people in the entire world. This situation has been labeled â€œsix degrees of separationâ€ (GuareÂ 1990), a phrase which has since passed into popular folklore.

Given the form of Milgramâ€™s experiment, one could be forgiven for supposing that the figure six is probably not a very accurate one. The experiment certainly contained many possible sources of error. However, the general result that two randomly chosen human beings can be connected by only a short chain of intermediate acquaintances has been subsequently verified, and is now widely accepted (Korte and MilgramÂ 1970). In the jargon of the field this result is referred to as the small-world effect.

The small-world effect applies to networks other than networks of friends. Brett Tjadenâ€™s parlor game â€œThe Six Degrees of Kevin Baconâ€ connects any pair of film actors via a chain of at most eight co-stars (Tjaden and WassonÂ 1997). Tom Remes has done the same for baseball players who have played on the same team (RemesÂ 1997). With tongue very firmly in cheek, the New York Times played a similar game with the the names of those who had tangled with Monica Lewinsky (Kirby and SahreÂ 1998).

All of this however, seems somewhat frivolous. Why should a serious scientist care about the structure of social networks? The reason is that such networks are crucially important for communications. Most human communicationâ€”where the word is used in its broadest senseâ€”takes place directly between individuals. The spread of news, rumors, jokes, and fashions all take place by contact between individuals. And a rumor can spread from coast to coast far faster over a social network in which the average degree of separation is six, than it can over one in which the average degree is a hundred, or a million. More importantly still, the spread of disease also occurs by person-to-person contact, and the structure of networks of such contacts has a huge impact on the nature of epidemics. In a highly connected network, this yearâ€™s fluâ€”or the HIV virusâ€”can spread far faster than in a network where the paths between individuals are relatively long.

In this paper we outline some recent developments in the theory of social networks, particularly in the characterization and modeling of networks, and in the modeling of the spread of information or disease.

The simplest explanation for the small-world effect uses the idea of a random graph. Suppose there is some number Nğ‘italic-NN of people in the world, and on average they each have zğ‘§italic-zz acquaintances. This means that there are 12â¢Nâ¢z12ğ‘ğ‘§FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-N italic-z\mbox{$\frac{1}{2}$}Nz connections between people in the entire population. The number zğ‘§italic-zz is called the coordination number of the network.

We can make a very simple model of a social network by taking Nğ‘italic-NN dots (â€œnodesâ€ or â€œverticesâ€) and drawing 12â¢Nâ¢z12ğ‘ğ‘§FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-N italic-z\mbox{$\frac{1}{2}$}Nz lines (â€œedgesâ€) between randomly chosen pairs to represent these connections. Such a network is called a random graph (BollobÃ¡sÂ 1985). Random graphs have been studied extensively in the mathematics community, particularly by ErdÃ¶s and RÃ©nyiÂ (1959). It is easy to see that a random graph shows the small-world effect. If a personÂ A on such a graph has zğ‘§italic-zz neighbors, and each of Aâ€™s neighbors also has zğ‘§italic-zz neighbors, then A has about z2superscriptğ‘§2italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{2} second neighbors. Extending this argument A also has z3superscriptğ‘§3italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{3} third neighbors, z4superscriptğ‘§4italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{4} fourth neighbors and so on. Most people have between a hundred and a thousand acquaintances, so z4superscriptğ‘§4italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{4} is already between about 108superscript108NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{8} and 1012superscript1012NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{12}, which is comparable with the population of the world. In general the number Dğ·italic-DD of degrees of separation which we need to consider in order to reach all Nğ‘italic-NN people in the network (also called the diameter of the graph) is given by setting zD=Nsuperscriptğ‘§ğ·ğ‘italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-Nz^{D}=N, which implies that D=logâ¡N/logâ¡zğ·ğ‘ğ‘§italic-D RELOP:equals OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-N MULOP:divide OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-zD=\log N/\log z. This logarithmic increase in the number of degrees of separation with the size of the network is typical of the small-world effect. Since logâ¡Nğ‘OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-N\log N increases only slowly with Nğ‘italic-NN, it allows the number of degrees to be quite small even in very large systems.

As an example of this type of behavior, AlbertÂ etÂ al.Â (1999) studied the properties of the network of â€œhyperlinksâ€ between documents on the World Wide Web. They estimated that, despite the fact there were Nâ‰ƒ8Ã—108similar-to-or-equalsğ‘8superscript108italic-N RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:8 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN\simeq 8\times 10^{8} documents on the Web at the time the study was carried out, the average distance between documents was only aboutÂ 19.

There is a significant problem with the random graph as a model of social networks however. The problem is that peopleâ€™s circles of acquaintance tend to overlap to a great extent. Your friendâ€™s friends are likely also to be your friends, or to put it another way, two of your friends are likely also to be friends with one another. This means that in a real social network it is not true to say that personÂ A has z2superscriptğ‘§2italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{2} second neighbors, since many of those friends of friends are also themselves friends of personÂ A. This property is called clustering of networks.

th.class: ltx_td ltx_align_left ltx_th ltx_th_column ltx_th_row ltx_border_r
ltx_td ltx_align_left ltx_th ltx_th_row ltx_border_r ltx_border_t

figure.figcaption: Table 1: The number of nodes Nğ‘italic-NN, average degree of separation â„“â„“ell\ell, and clustering coefficient Cğ¶italic-CC, for three real-world networks. The last column is the value which Cğ¶italic-CC would take in a random graph with the same size and coordination number.

div.p: A random graph does not show clustering. In a random graph the probability that two of personÂ Aâ€™s friends will be friends of one another is no greater than the probability that two randomly chosen people will be. On the other hand, clustering has been shown to exist in a number of real-world networks. One can define a clustering coefficient Cğ¶italic-CC, which is the average fraction of pairs of neighbors of a node which are also neighbors of each other. In a fully connected network, in which everyone knows everyone else, C=1ğ¶1italic-C RELOP:equals NUMBER:1C=1; in a random graph C=z/Nğ¶ğ‘§ğ‘italic-C RELOP:equals italic-z MULOP:divide italic-NC=z/N, which is very small for a large network. In real-world networks it has been found that, while Cğ¶italic-CC is significantly less thanÂ 1, it is much greater than Oâ¢(N-1)Osuperscriptğ‘1O OPEN:( italic-N POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){\rm O}(N^{-1}). In TableÂ 1, we show some values of Cğ¶italic-CC calculated by Watts and StrogatzÂ (1998) for three different networks: the network of collaborations between movie actors discussed previously, the neural network of the worm C.Â Elegans, and the Western Power Grid of the United States. We also give the value Crandsubscriptğ¶randitalic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start rand POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{\rm rand} which the clustering coefficient would have on random graphs of the same size and coordination number, and in each case the measured value is significantly higher than for the random graph, indicating that indeed the graph is clustered.

In the same table we also show the average distance â„“â„“ell\ell between pairs of nodes in each of these networks. This is not the same as the diameter Dğ·italic-DD of the network discussed above, which is the maximum distance between nodes, but it also scales at most logarithmically with number of nodes on random graphs. This is easy to see, since the average distance is strictly less than or equal to the maximum distance, and so â„“â„“ell\ell cannot increase any faster than Dğ·italic-DD. As the table shows, the value of â„“â„“ell\ell in each of the networks considered is small, indicating that the small-world effect is at work. (The precise definition of â€œsmall-world effectâ€ is still a matter of debate, but in the present case a reasonable definition would be that â„“â„“ell\ell should be comparable with the value it would have on the random graph, which for the systems discussed here it is.)

So, if random graphs do not match well the properties of real-world networks, is there an alternative model which does? Such a model has been suggested by Duncan Watts and Steven Strogatz. It is described in the next section.

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: (a)Â A one-dimensional lattice with each site connected to its zğ‘§italic-zz nearest neighbors, where in this case z=6ğ‘§6italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:6z=6. (b)Â The same lattice with periodic boundary conditions, so that the system becomes a ring. (c)Â The Wattsâ€“Strogatz model is created by rewiring a small fraction of the links (in this case five of them) to new sites chosen at random.

section.h2: 3 The small-world model of Watts and Strogatz

div.p: In order to model the real-world networks described in the last section, we need to find a way of generating graphs which have both the clustering and small-world properties. As we have argued, random graphs show the small-world effect, possessing average vertex-to-vertex distances which increase only logarithmically with the total number Nğ‘italic-NN of vertices, but they do not show clusteringâ€”the property that two neighbors of a vertex will often also be neighbors of one another.

The opposite of a random graph, in some sense, is a completely ordered lattice, the simplest example of which is a one-dimensional latticeâ€”a set of vertices arranged in a straight line. If we take such a lattice and connect each vertex to the zğ‘§italic-zz vertices closest to it, as in Fig.Â 1a, then it is easy to see that most of the immediate neighbors of any site are also neighbors of one another, i.e.,Â it shows the clustering property. Normally, we apply periodic boundary conditions to the lattice, so that it wraps around on itself in a ring (Fig.Â 1b), although this is just for convenience and not strictly necessary. For such a lattice we can calculate the clustering coefficient Cğ¶italic-CC exactly. As long as z<23â¢Nğ‘§23ğ‘italic-z RELOP:less-than FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end italic-Nz<\frac{2}{3}N, which it will be for almost all graphs, we find that

semantics.annotation: italic-C RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 OPEN:( italic-z ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 OPEN:( italic-z ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: which tends to 3434FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end\frac{3}{4} in the limit of large zğ‘§italic-zz. We can also build networks out of higher-dimensional lattices, such as square or cubic lattices, and these also show the clustering property. The value of the clustering coefficient in general dimension dğ‘‘italic-dd is

semantics.annotation: italic-C RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 OPEN:( italic-z ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-d CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 OPEN:( italic-z ADDOP:minus italic-d CLOSE:) ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: which also tends to 3434FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end\frac{3}{4} for zâ‰«2â¢dmuch-greater-thanğ‘§2ğ‘‘italic-z RELOP:much-greater-than NUMBER:2 italic-dz\gg 2d.

Low-dimensional regular lattices however do not show the small-world effect of typical vertexâ€“vertex distances which increase only slowly with system size. It is straightforward to show that for a regular lattice in dğ‘‘italic-dd dimensions which has the shape of a square or (hyper)cube of side Lğ¿italic-LL, and therefore has N=Ldğ‘superscriptğ¿ğ‘‘italic-N RELOP:equals italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN=L^{d} vertices, the average vertexâ€“vertex distance increases as Lğ¿italic-LL, or equivalently as N1/dsuperscriptğ‘1ğ‘‘italic-N POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN^{1/d}. For small values of dğ‘‘italic-dd this does not give us small-world behavior. In one dimension for example, it means that the average distance increases linearly with system size. If we allow the dimension dğ‘‘italic-dd of the lattice to become large, then N1/dsuperscriptğ‘1ğ‘‘italic-N POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN^{1/d} becomes a slowly increasing function of Nğ‘italic-NN, and so the lattice does show the small-world effect. Could this be the explanation for what we see in real networks? Perhaps real networks are roughly regular lattices of very high dimension. This explanation is in fact not unreasonable, although it has not been widely discussed. It works quite well, provided the mean coordination number zğ‘§italic-zz of the vertices is much higher than twice the dimension dğ‘‘italic-dd of the lattice. (If we allow zğ‘§italic-zz to approach 2â¢d2ğ‘‘NUMBER:2 italic-d2d, then the clustering coefficient, Eq.Â (2), tends to zero, implying that the lattice loses its clustering properties.)

Watts and StrogatzÂ (1998) however have proposed an alternative model for the small world, which perhaps fits better with our everyday intuitions about the nature of social networks. Their suggestion was to build a model which is, in essence, a low-dimensional regular latticeâ€”say a one-dimensional latticeâ€”but which has some degree of randomness in it, like a random graph, to produce the small-world effect. They suggested a specific scheme for doing this as follows. We take the one-dimensional lattice of Fig.Â 1b, and we go through each of the links on the lattice in turn and, with some probability pğ‘italic-pp, we randomly â€œrewireâ€ that link, meaning that we move one of its ends to a new position chosen at random from the rest of the lattice. For small pğ‘italic-pp this produces a graph with is still mostly regular but has a few connections which stretch long distances across the lattice as in Fig.Â 1c. The coordination number of the lattice is still zğ‘§italic-zz on average as it was before, although the number of neighbors of any particular vertex can be greater or smaller than zğ‘§italic-zz.

In social terms, we can justify this model by saying that, while most people are friends with their immediate neighborsâ€”neighbors on the same street, people that they work with, people that their friends introduce them toâ€”some people are also friends with one or two people who are a long way away, in some social senseâ€”people in other countries, people from other walks of life, acquaintances from previous eras of their lives, and so forth. These long-distance acquaintances are represented by the long-range links in the model of Watts and Strogatz.

Clearly the values of the clustering coefficient Cğ¶italic-CC for the Wattsâ€“Strogatz model with small values of pğ‘italic-pp will be close to those for the perfectly ordered lattice given above, which tend toÂ 3434FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end\frac{3}{4} for fixed small dğ‘‘italic-dd and large zğ‘§italic-zz. Watts and Strogatz also showed by numerical simulation that the average vertexâ€“vertex distance â„“â„“ell\ell is comparable with that for a true random graph, even for quite small values of pğ‘italic-pp. For example, for a random graph with N=1000ğ‘1000italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:1000N=1000 and z=10ğ‘§10italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:10z=10, they found that the average distance was about â„“=3.2â„“3.2ell RELOP:equals NUMBER:3.2\ell=3.2 between two vertices chosen at random. For their rewiring model, the average distance was only slightly greater, at â„“=3.6â„“3.6ell RELOP:equals NUMBER:3.6\ell=3.6, when the rewiring probability p=14ğ‘14italic-p RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:endp=\frac{1}{4}, compared with â„“=50â„“50ell RELOP:equals NUMBER:50\ell=50 for the graph with no rewired links at all. And even for p=164=0.0156ğ‘1640.0156italic-p RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:64 ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.0156p=\frac{1}{64}=0.0156, they found â„“=7.4â„“7.4ell RELOP:equals NUMBER:7.4\ell=7.4, a little over twice the value for the random graph. Thus the model appears to show both the clustering and small-world properties simultaneously. This result has since been confirmed by further simulation as well as analytic work on small-world models, which is described in the next section.

section.h2: 4 Analytic and numerical results for small-world models

div.p: Most of the recent work on models of the small world has been performed using a variation of the Wattsâ€“Strogatz model suggested by Newman and WattsÂ (1999a). In this version of the model, instead of rewiring links between sites as in Fig.Â 1c, extra links, often called shortcuts, are added between pairs of sites chosen at random, but no links are removed from the underlying lattice. This model is somewhat easier to analyze than the original Wattsâ€“Strogatz model, because it is not possible for any region of the graph to become disconnected from the rest, whereas this can happen in the original model. Mathematically a disjoint section of the graph can be represented by saying that the distance from any vertex in that section to a vertex somewhere on the rest of the graph is infinite. However, this means that, when averaged over all possible realizations of the graph, the average vertexâ€“vertex distance â„“â„“ell\ell in the model is also infinite for any finite value of pğ‘italic-pp. (A similar problem in the theory of random graphs is commonly dealt with by averaging the reciprocal of vertexâ€“vertex distance, rather than the distance itself, but this approach does not seem to have been tried for the Wattsâ€“Strogatz model.) In fact, it is possible to show that the series expansion of â„“/Lâ„“ğ¿ell MULOP:divide italic-L\ell/L in powers of pğ‘italic-pp about p=0ğ‘0italic-p RELOP:equals NUMBER:0p=0 is well-behaved up to order pz-1superscriptğ‘ğ‘§1italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-z ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endp^{z-1}, but that the expansion coefficients are infinite for all higher orders. For the version of the model where no links are ever removed, the expansion coefficients take the same values up to order pz-1superscriptğ‘ğ‘§1italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-z ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endp^{z-1}, but are finite for all higher orders as well. Generically, both versions of the model are referred to as small-world models, or sometimes small-world graphs.

Many results have been derived for small-world models, and many of their other properties have been explored numerically. Here we give only a brief summary of the most important results. BarthÃ©lÃ©my and AmaralÂ (1999) conjectured that the average vertexâ€“vertex distance â„“â„“ell\ell obeys the scaling form â„“=Î¾â¢Gâ¢(L/Î¾)â„“ğœ‰ğºğ¿ğœ‰ell RELOP:equals italic-xi italic-G OPEN:( italic-L MULOP:divide italic-xi CLOSE:)\ell=\xi G(L/\xi), where Gâ¢(x)ğºğ‘¥italic-G OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)G(x) is a universal scaling function of its argument xğ‘¥italic-xx and Î¾ğœ‰italic-xi\xi is a characteristic length-scale for the model which is assumed to diverge in the limit of small pğ‘italic-pp according to Î¾âˆ¼p-Ï„similar-toğœ‰superscriptğ‘ğœitalic-xi RELOP:similar-to italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-tau POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\xi\sim p^{-\tau}. On the basis of numerical results, BarthÃ©lÃ©my and Amaral further conjectured that Ï„=23ğœ23italic-tau RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end\tau=\frac{2}{3}. BarratÂ (1999) disproved this second conjecture using a simple physical argument which showed that Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau cannot be less thanÂ 1, and suggested on the basis of more numerical results that in fact it was exactlyÂ 1. Newman and WattsÂ (1999b) showed that the small-world model has only one non-trivial length-scale other than the lattice spacing, which we can equate with the variable Î¾ğœ‰italic-xi\xi above, and which is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-xi RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-p italic-z ARG:end

div.p: for the one-dimensional model, or

semantics.annotation: italic-xi RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start OPEN:( italic-p italic-z italic-d CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end

div.p: in the general case. Thus Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau must indeed beÂ 1 for d=1ğ‘‘1italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:1d=1, or Ï„=1/dğœ1ğ‘‘italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-d\tau=1/d for general dğ‘‘italic-dd and, since there are no other length-scales present, â„“â„“ell\ell must be of the form

semantics.annotation: ell RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-L ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-d italic-z ARG:end italic-F OPEN:( italic-p italic-z italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: where Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥italic-F OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)F(x) is another universal scaling function. (The initial factor of (2â¢d)-1superscript2ğ‘‘1OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-d CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(2d)^{-1} before the scaling function is arbitrary. It is chosen thus to give Fğ¹italic-FF a simple limit for small values of its argumentâ€”see Eq.Â (6).) This scaling form is equivalent to that of BarthÃ©lÃ©my and Amaral by the substitution Gâ¢(x)=xâ¢Fâ¢(x)ğºğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¥italic-G OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-x italic-F OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)G(x)=xF(x) if Ï„=1ğœ1italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\tau=1. It has been extensively confirmed by numerical simulation (Newman and WattsÂ 1999a, deÂ MenezesÂ etÂ al.Â 2000) and by series expansions (Newman and WattsÂ 1999b) (see Fig.Â 2). The divergence of Î¾ğœ‰italic-xi\xi as pâ†’0â†’ğ‘0italic-p ARROW:to NUMBER:0p\to 0 gives something akin to a critical point in this limit. (De MenezesÂ etÂ al.Â (2000) have argued that, for technical reasons, we should refer to this point as a â€œfirst order critical pointâ€ (Fisher and BerkerÂ 1982).) This allowed Newman and WattsÂ (1999a) to apply a real-space renormalization group transformation to the model in the vicinity of this point and prove that the scaling form above is exactly obeyed in the limit of small pğ‘italic-pp and large Lğ¿italic-LL.

Eq.Â (5) tells us that although the average vertexâ€“vertex distance on a small-world graph appears at first glance to be a function of three parametersâ€”pğ‘italic-pp, zğ‘§italic-zz, and Lğ¿italic-LLâ€”it is in fact entirely determined by a single scalar function of a single scalar variable. If we know the form of this one function, then we know everything. Actually, this statement is strictly only true if Î¾â‰«1much-greater-thanğœ‰1italic-xi RELOP:much-greater-than NUMBER:1\xi\gg 1, when it is safe to ignore the other length-scale in the problem, the lattice parameter of the underlying lattice. Thus, the scaling form is expected to hold only when pğ‘italic-pp is small, i.e.,Â in the regime where the majority of a personâ€™s contacts are local and only a small fraction long-range. (The fourth parameter dğ‘‘italic-dd also enters the equation, but is not on an equal footing with the others, since the functional form of Fğ¹italic-FF changes with dğ‘‘italic-dd, and thus Eq.Â (5) does not tell us how â„“â„“ell\ell varies with dimension.)

figure.figcaption: Figure 2: Scaling collapse of average vertexâ€“vertex distances on d=1ğ‘‘1italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:1d=1 small-world graphs according to Eq.Â (5). Points are numerical data for z=2ğ‘§2italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:2z=2 (circles) and z=10ğ‘§10italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:10z=10 (squares), for a variety of values of pğ‘italic-pp and Lğ¿italic-LL. The solid line is a PadÃ© approximant derived from series expansions of the scaling function, while the dotted line is the mean-field solution, Eq.Â (8). Inset: the number of people infected as a function of time by a disease which starts with a single person and spreads through a community with the topology of a small-world graph. After Newman and WattsÂ (1999b) and NewmanÂ etÂ al.Â (2000).

div.p: Both the scaling function Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥italic-F OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)F(x) and the scaling variable xâ‰¡pâ¢zâ¢Ldğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘§superscriptğ¿ğ‘‘italic-x RELOP:equivalent-to italic-p italic-z italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx\equiv pzL^{d} have simple physical interpretations. The variable xğ‘¥italic-xx is two times the average number of shortcuts on the graph for the given value of pğ‘italic-pp, and Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥italic-F OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)F(x) is the average fraction by which the vertexâ€“vertex distance on the graph is reduced for the given value of xğ‘¥italic-xx. From the results shown in Fig.Â 2, we can see that it takes about 5â¤12512ADDOP:plus NUMBER:5 FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end5\frac{1}{2} shortcuts to reduce the average vertex-vertex distance by a factor of two, and 56 to reduce it by a factor of ten.

In the limit of large pğ‘italic-pp the small-world model becomes a random graph or nearly so. Hence, we expect that the value of â„“â„“ell\ell should scale logarithmically with system size Lğ¿italic-LL when pğ‘italic-pp is large, and also, as the scaling form shows, when Lğ¿italic-LL is large. On the other hand, when pğ‘italic-pp or Lğ¿italic-LL is small we expect â„“â„“ell\ell to scale linearly with Lğ¿italic-LL. This implies that Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥italic-F OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)F(x) has the limiting forms

semantics.annotation: italic-F OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:{ ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:1 CELL:end CELL:start for italic-x RELOP:much-less-than NUMBER:1 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start OPEN:( OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-x CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-x CELL:end CELL:start for italic-x RELOP:much-greater-than NUMBER:1 . CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end

div.p: In theory there should be a leading constant in front of the large-xğ‘¥italic-xx form here, but, as discussed shortly, it turns out that this constant is equal to unity. The cross-over between the small- and large-xğ‘¥italic-xx regimes must happen in the vicinity of L=Î¾ğ¿ğœ‰italic-L RELOP:equals italic-xiL=\xi, since Î¾ğœ‰italic-xi\xi is the only length-scale available to dictate this point.

Neither the actual distribution of path lengths in the small-world model nor the average path length â„“â„“ell\ell has been calculated exactly yet; exact analytical calculations have proven very difficult for the model. Some exact results have been given by KulkarniÂ etÂ al.Â (2000) who show, for example, that the value of â„“â„“ell\ell is simply related to the mean âŸ¨sâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ OPEN:langle italic-s CLOSE:rangle\langle s\rangle and mean square âŸ¨s2âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ‘ 2OPEN:langle italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\langle s^{2}\rangle of the shortest distance sğ‘ italic-ss between two points on diametrically opposite sides of the graph, according to

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start ell ARG:end ARG:start italic-L ARG:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPEN:langle italic-s CLOSE:rangle ARG:end ARG:start italic-L ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 ARG:end ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPEN:langle italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle ARG:end ARG:start italic-L OPEN:( italic-L ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: Unfortunately, calculating the shortest distance between opposite points is just as difficult as calculating â„“â„“ell\ell directly, either analytically or numerically.

NewmanÂ etÂ al.Â (2000) have calculated the form of the scaling function Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥italic-F OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)F(x) for d=1ğ‘‘1italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:1d=1 small-world graphs using a mean-field-like approximation, which is exact for small or large values of xğ‘¥italic-xx, but not in the regime where xâ‰ƒ1similar-to-or-equalsğ‘¥1italic-x RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:1x\simeq 1. Their result is

semantics.annotation: italic-F OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end ARG:start italic-square-root ARG:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:4 italic-x ARG:end ARG:end TRIGFUNCTION:hyperbolic-tangent POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-x ARG:end ARG:start italic-square-root ARG:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:4 italic-x ARG:end ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: This form is also plotted on Fig.Â 2 (dotted line). Since this is exact for large xğ‘¥italic-xx, it can be expanded about 1/x=01ğ‘¥0NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:01/x=0 to show that the leading constant in the large-xğ‘¥italic-xx form of Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥italic-F OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)F(x), Eq.Â (6), isÂ 11NUMBER:11 as stated above.

NewmanÂ etÂ al.Â also solved for the complete distribution of lengths between vertices in the model within their mean-field approximation. This distribution can be used to give a simple model of the spread of a disease in a small world. If a disease starts with a single person somewhere in the world, and spreads first to all the neighbors of that person, and then to all second neighbors, and so on, then the number of people nğ‘›italic-nn who have the disease after tğ‘¡italic-tt time-steps is simply the number of people who are separated from the initial carrier by a distance of tğ‘¡italic-tt or less. Newman and WattsÂ (1999b) previously gave an approximate differential equation for nâ¢(t)ğ‘›ğ‘¡italic-n OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)n(t) on an infinite small-world graph, which they solved for the one-dimensional case; MoukarzelÂ (1999) later solved it for the case of generalÂ dğ‘‘italic-dd. The mean-field treatment generalizes the solution for d=1ğ‘‘1italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:1d=1 to finite lattice sizes. (A similar mean-field result has been given for a slightly different disease-spreading model by Kleczkowski and GrenfellÂ (1999).) The resulting form for nâ¢(t)ğ‘›ğ‘¡italic-n OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)n(t) is shown in the inset of Fig.Â 2, and clearly has the right general sigmoidal shape for the spread of an epidemic. In fact, this form of nğ‘›italic-nn is typical also of the standard logistic growth models of disease spread, which are mostly based on random graphs (Sattenspiel and SimonÂ 1988, Kretschmar and MorrisÂ 1996). In the next section we consider some (slightly) more sophisticated models of disease spreading on small-world graphs.

section.h2: 5 Other models based on small-world graphs

div.p: A variety of authors have looked at dynamical systems defined on small-world graphs built using either the Wattsâ€“Strogatz rewiring method or the alternative method described in SectionÂ 4. We briefly describe a number of these studies in this section.

Watts and StrogatzÂ (1998, WattsÂ 1999) looked at cellular automata, simple games, and networks of coupled oscillators on small-world networks. For example, they found that it was much easier for a cellular automaton to perform the task known as density classification (DasÂ etÂ al.Â 1994) on a small-world graph than on a regular lattice; they found that in an iterated multi-player game of Prisonerâ€™s Dilemma, cooperation arose less frequently on a small-world graph than on a regular lattice; and they found that the small-world topology helped oscillator networks to synchronize much more easily than in the regular lattice case.

MonassonÂ (1999) investigated the eigenspectrum of the Laplacian operator on small-world graphs using a transfer matrix method. This spectrum tells us for example what the normal modes would be of a system of masses and springs built with the topology of a small-world graph. Or, perhaps more usefully, it can tell us how diffusive dynamics would occur on a small world graph; any initial state of a diffusive field can be decomposed into eigenvectors which each decay independently and exponentially with a decay constant related to the corresponding eigenvalue. Diffusive motion might provide a simple model for the spread of information of some kind in a social network.

Barrat and WeigtÂ (2000) have given a solution of the ferromagnetic Ising model on a d=1ğ‘‘1italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:1d=1 small-world network using a replica method. Since the Ising model has a lower critical dimension of two, we would expect it not to show a phase transition when p=0ğ‘0italic-p RELOP:equals NUMBER:0p=0 and the graph is truly one-dimensional. On the other hand, as soon as pğ‘italic-pp is greater than zero, the effective dimension of the graph becomes greater than one, and increases with system size (Newman and WattsÂ 1999b). Thus for any finite pğ‘italic-pp we would expect to see a phase transition at some finite temperature in the large system limit. Barrat and Weigt confirmed both analytically and numerically that indeed this is the case. The Ising model is of course a highly idealized model, and its solution in this context is, to a large extent, just an interesting exercise. However, the similar problem of a Potts antiferromagnet on a general graph has real practical applications, e.g.,Â in the solution of scheduling problems. Although this problem has not been solved on the small-world graph, WalshÂ (1999) has found results which indicate that it may be interesting from a computational complexity point of view; finding a ground state for a Potts antiferromagnet on a small-world graph may be significantly harder than finding one on either a regular lattice or a random graph.

Newman and WattsÂ (1999b) looked at the problem of disease spread on small-world graphs. As a first step away from the very simple models of disease described in the last section, they considered a disease to which only a certain fraction qğ‘italic-qq of the population is susceptible; the disease spreads neighbor to neighbor on a small-world graph, except that it only affects, and can be transmitted by, the susceptible individuals. In such a model, the disease can only spread within the connected cluster of susceptible individuals in which it first starts, which is small if qğ‘italic-qq is small, but becomes larger, and eventually infinite, as qğ‘italic-qq increases. The point at which it becomes infiniteâ€”the point at which an epidemic takes placeâ€”is precisely the percolation point for site percolation with probability qğ‘italic-qq on the small-world graph. Newman and Watts gave an approximate calculation of this epidemic point, which compares reasonably favorably with their numerical simulations. Moore and NewmanÂ (2000a, 2000b) later gave an exact solution.

Lago-FernÃ¡ndezÂ etÂ al.Â (2000) investigated the behavior of a neural network of Hodgkinâ€“Huxley neurons on a variety of graphs, including regular lattices, random graphs, and small-world graphs. They found that the presence of a high degree of clustering in the network allowed the network to establish coherent oscillation, while short average vertexâ€“vertex distances allowed the network to produce fast responses to changes in external stimuli. The small-world graph, which simultaneously possesses both of these properties, was the only graph they investigated which showed both coherence and fast response.

KulkarniÂ etÂ al.Â (1999) studied numerically the behavior of the Bakâ€“Sneppen model of species coevolution (Bak and SneppenÂ 1993) on small-world graphs. This is a model which mimics the evolutionary effects of interactions between large numbers of species. The behavior of the model is known to depend on the topology of the lattice on which it is situated, and Kulkarni and co-workers suggested that the topology of the small-world graph might be closer to that of interactions in real ecosystems than the low-dimensional regular lattices on which the Bakâ€“Sneppen model is usually studied. The principal result of the simulations was that on a small-world graph the amount of evolutionary activity taking place at any given vertex varies with the coordination number of the vertex, with the most connected nodes showing the greatest activity and the least connected ones showing the smallest.

section.h2: 6 Other models of the small world

div.p: Although most of the work reviewed in this article is based on the Wattsâ€“Strogatz small-world model, a number of other models of social networks have been proposed. In SectionÂ 2 we mentioned the simple random-graph model and in SectionÂ 3 we discussed a model based on a regular lattice of high dimension. In this section we describe briefly three others which have been suggested.

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: An alternative model of a small world, in which there are a small number of individuals who are connected to many widely-distributed acquaintances.

div.p: One alternative to the view put forward by Watts and Strogatz is that the small-world phenomenon arises not because there are a few â€œlong-rangeâ€ connections in the otherwise short-range structure of a social network, but because there are a few nodes in the network which have unusually high coordination numbers (KasturiranganÂ 1999) or which are linked to a widely distributed set of neighbors. Perhaps the â€œsix degrees of separationâ€ effect is due to a few people who are particularly well connected. (GladwellÂ (1998) has written a lengthy and amusing article arguing that a septuagenarian salon proprietor in Chicago named Lois Weisberg is an example of precisely such a person.) A simple model of this kind of network is depicted in Fig.Â 3, in which we start again with a one-dimensional lattice, but instead of adding extra links between pairs of sites, we add a number of extra vertices in the middle which are connected to a large number of sites on the main lattice, chosen at random. (Lois Weisberg would be one of these extra sites.) This model is similar to the Wattsâ€“Strogatz model in that the addition of the extra sites effectively introduces shortcuts between randomly chosen positions on the lattice, so it should not be surprising to learn that this model does display the small-world effect. In fact, even in the case where only one extra site is added, the model shows the small-world effect if that site is sufficiently highly connected. This case has been solved exactly by Dorogovtsev and MendesÂ (1999).

Another alternative model of the small world has been suggested by AlbertÂ etÂ al.Â (1999) who, in their studies of the World Wide Web discussed in SectionÂ 2, concluded that the Web is dominated by a small number of very highly connected sites, as described above, but they also found that the distribution of the coordination numbers of sites (the number of â€œhyperlinksâ€ pointing to or from a site) was a power-law, rather than being bimodal as it is in the previous model. They produced a model network of this kind as follows. Starting with a normal random graph with average coordination number zğ‘§italic-zz and the desired number Nğ‘italic-NN of vertices, they selected a vertex at random and added a link between it and another randomly chosen site if that addition would bring the overall distribution of coordination numbers closer to the required power law. Otherwise the vertex remains as it is. If this process is repeated for a sufficiently long time, a network is generated with the correct coordination numbers, but which is in other respects a random graph. In particular, it does not show the clustering property of which such a fuss has been made in the case of the Wattsâ€“Strogatz model. AlbertÂ etÂ al.Â found that their model matched the measured properties of the World Wide Web quite closely, although related work by AdamicÂ (1999) indicates that clustering is present in the Web, so that the model is unrealistic in this respect.

It is worth noting that networks identical to those of AlbertÂ etÂ al.Â can be generated in a manner much more efficient than the Monte Carlo scheme described above by simply generating Nğ‘italic-NN vertices with a power law distribution of lines emerging from them (using, for instance, the transformation method (Newman and BarkemaÂ 1999)), and then joining pairs of lines together at random until none are left. If one were interested in investigating such networks numerically, this would probably be the best way to generate them.

A third suggestion has been put forward by KleinbergÂ (1999), who argues that a model such as that of Watts and Strogatz, in which shortcuts connect vertices arbitrarily far apart with uniform probability, is a poor representation of at least some real-world situations. (KasturiranganÂ (1999) has made a similar point.) Kleinberg notes that in the real world, people are surprisingly good at finding short paths between pairs of individuals (Milgramâ€™s letter experiment, and the Kevin Bacon game are good examples) given only local information about the structure of the network. Conversely, he has shown that no algorithm exists which is capable of finding such paths on networks of the Wattsâ€“Strogatz type, again given only local information. Thus there must be some additional properties of real-world networks which make it possible to find short paths with ease. To investigate this question further, Kleinberg has proposed a generalization of the Wattsâ€“Strogatz model in which the typical distance traversed by the shortcuts can be tuned. Kleinbergâ€™s model is based on a two-dimensional square lattice (although it could be generalized to other dimensions dğ‘‘italic-dd in a straightforward fashion) and has shortcuts added between pairs of vertices i,jğ‘–ğ‘—italic-i PUNCT:, italic-ji,j with probability which falls off as a power law diâ¢j-rsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘Ÿitalic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endd_{ij}^{\,-r} of the distance between them. (In this work, diâ¢jsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:endd_{ij} is the â€œManhattan distanceâ€ |xi-xj|+|yi-yj|subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—VERTBAR:| italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| ADDOP:plus VERTBAR:| italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||x_{i}-x_{j}|+|y_{i}-y_{j}|, where (xi,yi)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(x_{i},y_{i}) and (xj,yj)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(x_{j},y_{j}) are the lattice coordinates of the vertices iğ‘–italic-ii and jğ‘—italic-jj. This makes good sense, since this is also the distance in terms of links on the underlying lattice that separates those two points before the shortcuts are added. However, one could in principle generate networks using a different definition of distance, such as the Euclidean distance (xi-xj)2+(yi-yj)2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—2italic-square-root ARG:start OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus OPEN:( italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end\sqrt{(x_{i}-x_{j})^{2}+(y_{i}-y_{j})^{2}}, for example.) It is then shown that for the particular value r=2ğ‘Ÿ2italic-r RELOP:equals NUMBER:2r=2 of the exponent of the power law (or r=dğ‘Ÿğ‘‘italic-r RELOP:equals italic-dr=d for underlying lattices of dğ‘‘italic-dd dimensions), there exists a simple algorithm for finding a short path between two given vertices, making use only of local information. For any other value of rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr the problem of finding a short path is provably much harder. This result demonstrates that there is more to the small world effect than simply the existence of short paths.

In this article we have given an overview of recent theoretical work on the â€œsmall-worldâ€ phenomenon. We have described in some detail the considerable body of recent results dealing with the Wattsâ€“Strogatz small-world model and its variants, including analytic and numerical results about network structure and studies of dynamical systems on small-world graphs.

What have we learned from these efforts and where is this line of research going now? The most important result is that small-world graphsâ€”those possessing both short average person-to-person distances and â€œclusteringâ€ of acquaintancesâ€”show behaviors very different from either regular lattices or random graphs. Some of the more interesting such behaviors are the following:

These graphs show a transition with increasing number of vertices from a â€œlarge-worldâ€ regime in which the average distance between two people increases linearly with system size, to a â€œsmall-worldâ€ one in which it increases logarithmically.

This implies that information or disease spreading on a small-world graph reaches a number of people which increases initially as a power of time, then changes to an exponential increase, and then flattens off as the graph becomes saturated.

Disease models which incorporate a measure of susceptibility to infection have a percolation transition at which an epidemic sets in, whose position is influenced strongly by the small-world nature of the network.

Dynamical systems such as games or cellular automata show quantitatively different behavior on small-world graphs and regular lattices. Some problems, such as density classification, appear to be easier to solve on small-world graphs, while others, such as scheduling problems, appear to be harder.

Some real-world graphs show characteristics in addition to the small-world effect which may be important to their function. An example is the World Wide Web, which appears to have a scale-free distribution of the coordination numbers of vertices.

Research in this field is continuing in a variety of directions. Empirical work to determine the exact structure of real networks is underway in a number of groups, as well as theoretical work to determine the properties of the proposed models. And studies to determine the effects of the small-world topology on dynamical processes, although in their infancy, promise an intriguing new perspective on the way the world works.

The author would like to thank Luis Amaral, Marc BarthÃ©lÃ©my, Rahul Kulkarni, Cris Moore, Cristian Moukarzel, Naomi Sachs, Steve Strogatz, Toby Walsh, and Duncan Watts for useful discussions and comments. This work was supported in part by the Santa Fe Institute and DARPA under grant number ONR N00014-95-1-0975.
